quoteLast: , and a message from the _Southampton_, scouting ahead to the south, had suddenly transformed not only the immediate situation, but the entire future outlook of the action. quoteFirst: In July, the Queen and Prince took to their yacht again, for a visit to the Emperor and Empress, at Cherbourg, and had a grand reception, and there was a great _fête_, and fireworks and bombs and rockets; but the account is not half so interesting to me as the one given by Her Majesty, of their return to Osborne; an exquisite picture that, which I feel I must reproduce almost entire: ... "At
quoteLast: , we landed at our peaceful Osborne. ... The evening was very warm and calm. Dear Affie was on the pier, and we found all the other children, including Baby, standing at the door.
title: Queen Victoria, her girlhood and womanhood
author: Greenwood, Grace, 1823-1904

quoteFirst: We went on deck for a little while, but were driven below by the rain; later, however, it was possible to keep on deck. We reached _Campbeltown_, a small and not pretty place, at the foot of _Cantire_, at
quoteLast: . About half an hour after we arrived the yacht came in, with the “Garland,” “Fairy,” and “Scourge,” and we immediately went on board. They had had a very bad passage, and Captain Crispin said he was very glad that we had not been on board the “Victoria and Albert.
title: Leaves From the Journal of Our Life in the Highlands, From 1848 to 1861
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Helps, Arthur, Sir, 1813-1875 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Ducks.--At Tarbet Ness a large flock of ducks passed inland at 10 a.m., with a N. gale and snow, on Nov. 12th. At Girdleness, two ducks seen at
quoteLast: , wind S.W., and haze, on Oct. 16th. At Tarbet Ness a large flock seen at 9.15 a.m., wind W., strong and snow, on Dec. 5th. At Dunnet Head seven ducks (Widgeon) stayed on the lake three days from Oct. 25th; arrived with W. to N.W. breeze and cloudy.
title: Report on the Migration of Birds in the Autumn of 1879. [First Report]

quoteFirst: In the most difficult places rough ladders of bamboo are fixed. I counted fifteen brooks on the north-east side which feed the Catarman, and about the same number of feeders of the Calbayot on the south-west side. About
quoteLast: we reached the highest point of the Salta Sangley, about ninety feet above the sea; and at half-past six we got to a stream, the highest part of the Calbayot, in the bed of which we wandered until its increasing depth forced us, in the dark, laboriously to beat out our path through the underwood to its bank; and about eight o'clock we found ourselves opposite the visita Tragbucan.

quoteFirst: "It was after three, and she waited for you till
quoteLast: . Then she said she thought it would be interesting to go up to the orchard and gather apple-blossoms with rain-drops fresh on the petals. quoteFirst: Continuously throughout the night following the Battle of Five Forks, the Union artillery played upon the Confederate earthworks and dropped shells into the city. Troops were prepared for a general assault ordered for the following dawn. At
quoteLast: , April 2, 1865, a frontal attack began with the sound of a signal gun from Fort Fisher. A heavy ground fog added to the confusion as the Federals drove in the Confederate pickets, cut away the abatis, and stormed over the works.
title: Campaign for Petersburg
author: Lykes, Richard Wayne
